data.eligibility:

The business must be engaged in any business except: - Profession referred to in sections 44AA(1) and 44AA(2), i.e., professions like legal, medical, accountancy, technical consultancy, interior decoration, etc. - Business of commission or brokerage. - Business involving preservation or cultivation of land. - Income from speculative transactions.

data.beneficiaries:
The eligibility conditions for opting for Section 44AD include the following: 1. 

  • Nature of Business: The business must be engaged in any business except: - Profession referred to in sections 44AA(1) and 44AA(2), i.e., professions like legal, medical, accountancy, technical consultancy, interior decoration, etc. - 
  • Business of commission or brokerage. - Business involving preservation or cultivation of land. - Income from speculative transactions. 2. Turnover/Receipts Limit: The total turnover or gross receipts of the business in the financial year must be ₹2 crore or less. 3. 
  • Indian Resident: The taxpayer must be a resident individual, Hindu Undivided Family (HUF), or a sole proprietor. This scheme is not available for companies, LLPs, or firms. 4. No Audit Requirement: The taxpayer must not be required to maintain books under Section 44AA or undergo a tax audit under Section 44AB.
data.prerequisites:
1. Non-Applicability of Other Deductions: Once a taxpayer opts for Section 44AD, they cannot claim deductions under Chapter VI-A (e.g., deductions for investments, etc.) or expenses under Sections 30 to 38. The income declared under the scheme is treated as gross income, and no further expense deductions are allowed. 

2. No Loss Carry Forward: If the business under Section 44AD incurs a loss, it cannot carry forward the loss to future years because the scheme considers the income as presumptive. 

3. Withdrawal of Option: A taxpayer who opts for the scheme under Section 44AD cannot switch back to the regular taxation scheme for the next 5 years. 

4. Presumptive Income: The declared income (8% of gross receipts/turnover) is considered the final income for tax purposes, and no further adjustments for expenses are permitted, making it a simplified process. 

5. Digital Transaction Provision: If at least 95% of the total receipts are through digital modes (banking/electronic), then the deemed income is 6% rather than the standard 8%.
data.description:
1. Presumptive Taxation: Section 44AD offers a presumptive taxation scheme, where eligible businesses can declare 8% of their total turnover (or gross receipts) as their income for tax purposes, without maintaining detailed books of accounts. 
  2. No Requirement for Detailed Books: Businesses under this scheme do not need to maintain detailed books of accounts as required under Section 44AA (of the Income Tax Act), reducing administrative and compliance costs. 
  3. Fixed Percentage of Income: The income under this scheme is deemed to be 8% of the total turnover or gross receipts for a business in cash or non-cash transactions. In case of receipts from digital transactions (banking, electronic modes), the deemed income is 6%. 
  4. Simplified Filing: The scheme provides for a simpler way to compute income, making it easier for small business owners to file tax returns. No 
  5. Tax Audit Required: If the business opts for the presumptive taxation scheme under Section 44AD, they do not have to undergo a tax audit, which is typically mandatory for businesses with a turnover of over ₹1 crore. 
  6. Flat Tax Rate: Businesses opting for Section 44AD pay tax at the standard tax rates applicable for individual taxpayers (i.e., up to 30%, depending on the income). Advance Tax: Under this scheme, advance tax is not required to be paid in quarterly installments (it can be paid in one lump sum by 15th March of the financial year).
data.how_to_apply: The applicant can file ITR from Income Tax portal :https://www.incometax.gov.in/iec/foportal/
data.funding_mechanism:
1. The Sugam ITR 4 is a simplified return form to be used by an assessee if he is eligible to declare profits on a presumptive basis and does not maintain books of account u/s 44AD and 44AE. 
  2. An assessee is liable to pay his or her advance tax in a single installment on or before the 15th of March of every financial year if he or she opts for presumptive taxation under Section 44AD. 
  3. For any default in paying the advance tax , the assessee will be charged interest Section 234C.
